Award.AwardTitle: RII Track-4: Collaborative partnerships at the cusp of wildlife ecology and molecular biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Infrastructure Improvement RII Track-4 grant will examine how the migratory wildlife of Yellowstone National Park adjust their diets in response to seasonal change. Scientists need to understand how the plants that wild animals eat are able to fuel migrations in order to anticipate how the diversity of migratory wildlife and the routes that they select might change. This is especially important for large wildlife, such as bison and pronghorn antelope, that naturally engage in long-distance migrations across both public and private lands. This project will use cutting-edge molecular technologies to forensically identify the food plants that five species of wildlife eat during the course of their seasonal migrations. Each step of the work will enhance university teaching within Rhode Island, strengthen academic-government collaboration across multiple jurisdictions, and positively transform the career trajectory of the investigator. The proposed work establishes a new course-based undergraduate research program that enhances access and inclusion in mentored research at Brown University. In collaboration with scientists from the National Park Service, students will develop forensic methods to characterize animal diets and report results publicly. These goals will ensure the training of a diverse workforce with the experience needed to develop and communicate about the types of rapid genetic tests that are essential in modern environmental science, healthcare, and epidemiology.

Approaches emerging in wildlife biology and molecular biology can help advance ecology across scales from individual animal behaviors to the functioning of entire ecosystems. Animal diets are known to be important across these scales because food availability influences both individual movements and the ability of many species to coexist in a world of limited resources. However, theoretical frameworks that have developed with a focus on each of these different scales can generate conflicting predictions about how species will respond to environmental change. In this proposal, we focus on reconciling predictions about seasonality in the diets of an extensively studied assemblage of migratory large herbivores from Yellowstone National Park, which is North America’s most diverse large-herbivore community. Our proposal combines the investigator’s expertise in dietary DNA metabarcoding with the host site’s long-term GPS-tracking and field experimental data. We will test the hypotheses that (1) seasonal dietary shifts are predictable at scales spanning individuals to food webs and (2) feedbacks in seasonal plant-herbivore interactions modulate dietary overlap and specialization across these scales. The investigator, postdoctoral research associate, and students at Brown University will collaborate with scientists from the National Park Service to test these hypotheses. In the process, the team will generate and make publicly available a suite of biological resources that will have a long lifecycle of usefulness to research and education, including digital herbarium collections and a DNA reference library that are relevant across multiple EPSCoR jurisdictions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A wildlife population’s persistence in a changing world may depend upon how flexibly animals can eat new different foods under different conditions. The large herbivores that undertake ‘epic’ migrations across Yellowstone National Park—the bison, elk, deer, bighorn sheep, and pronghorn antelope—have evolved to use a huge diversity of plant species under conditions that vary from extreme heat to extreme cold. One prominent idea about how to explain this ability suggests that these species are “ecological generalists,” capable of thriving on a wide range of foods—but not all foods are equal and not all animals use the same strategies to find them. The difficulty of repeatedly sampling wildlife diets to quantify long-term changes in the diets of generalist species like these has long constrained ecologists’ abilities to understand, predict, and manage the effects of environmental changes on wildlife species and the complex food webs in which each resides. The major goal of this project was thus to help understand how predictably and consistently wildlife of different species modify their foraging strategies during the annual cycle in Yellowstone.

In close partnership with federal scientists, our team university researchers adopted an innovative approach to studying seasonal food webs called “DNA metabarcoding.” This strategy involves collecting herbivore dung, sequencing DNA of the plants they had eaten, and using a reference library of known food plants to quantify their diet composition. We studied the diets of animals that had been GPS-collared and tracked through various habitats by the National Park Service. We compared the diversity and uniqueness of food plants that these animals had eaten over the course of their annual migration. We also conducted vegetation surveys and began constructing a plant DNA reference library for the park, which will enhance the accuracy of similar studies in Yellowstone and across the Rocky Mountains more broadly. We found that these wildlife species responded predictably to seasonal changes in resource availability, and that the ways they update their foraging strategies is influenced by how big they are. For example, small pronghorn antelope “switched” their diets almost completely from summer foods to winter foods whereas large bison were uniquely able to maintain year-round access to staple food resources even in deep snow.

Thus far, the project has contributed to 3 peer-reviewed scientific publications and the training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers that either directly addressed the question of what foods fuel wildlife migrations in Yellowstone or more generally contributed to the development of laboratory and computational strategies required to apply genomic technologies to ecological questions. Three Brown University undergraduate students joined federal and academic researchers at Yellowstone National Park, 20 benefitted from research opportunities in the lab of the Principal Investigator at Brown University, and more than 60 graduate and undergraduate students gained hands-on experience via course-based research opportunities connected to this award. Support provided by this award strengthened partnerships between the National Park Service at Yellowstone and several academic institutions, seeding long-term ecological research in the park and the development of exemplary research strategies at the interaction of molecular biology and the environment more broadly.
